title: American Chamber Players returns to Temple of Israel
text:
American Chamber Players returns to Temple of Israel Paul Hyde , phyde@greenvillenews.com 7:03 p.m. EDT October 23, 2015 The American Chamber Players returns to Greenville’s Temple of Israel on Sunday. (Photo: Mary Noble Ours) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
As chamber music goes, it doesn’t get much more monumental than Brahms’ Piano Quartet No. 2 in A Major. 
The acclaimed American Chamber Players will perform the 50-minute work as the ensemble returns to Greenville’s Temple of Israel on Sunday. 
“We first played it a couple of years ago and I’ve fallen madly in love with it,” said Miles Hoffman, violist and founder of the five-member ensemble. 
“The length of it is one of its great appeals,” Hoffman said. “You feel like you’ve been on this enormous and profound voyage by the end of the work.” 
The American Chamber Players is a frequent annual guest on the Temple’s Music on Sunday series. 
The five musicians who comprise the group enjoy active performing and teaching careers in various parts of the country. Hoffman is the only resident of the Upstate. 
The members get together a few dozen times a year to perform as the Chamber Players. In addition to Hoffman on viola, the group includes violinist Joanna Maurer, flutist Sara Stern, cellist Stephen Balderston and pianist Anna Stoytcheva. 
“We love playing together, and we really enjoy each other’s company,” Hoffman said. “I always feel so thrilled and privileged to play with the other members of the group because they’re remarkable musicians and such wonderful people.” 
The group particularly relishes an opportunity to return to the Temple of Israel. 
“The acoustics there are just great,” Hoffman said. 
The ensemble’s program Sunday also will include the Trio in C Major for flute, violin and cello (“London” Trio No. 1) by Joseph Haydn. 
“It’s absolutely charming,” Hoffman said. 
Also featured will be the Trio in G Minor for flute, cello and piano by Carl Maria von Weber. 
“It’s one of Weber’s top-notch chamber music pieces,” Hoffman said. 
In addition to performing, Hoffman is a prominent radio commentator. He hosts the national radio broadcasts of “Chamber Music From the Spoleto Festival USA,” carried locally on South Carolina’s public radio stations. His “A Minute With Miles,” offering insights into classical music, is a three-time daily feature on South Carolina public radio as well. 
Hoffman also is a music commentator for National Public Radio’s flagship news program, “Morning Edition.” 
For the latest in local arts news and reviews, follow Paul Hyde on Facebook and Twitter: @PaulHyde7.
